titleStmt.title: CasCADe: A Novel 4D Visualization System for Virtual Construction Planning

analytic.title: CasCADe: A Novel 4D Visualization System for Virtual Construction Planning

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Fig. 1: CasCADe's unique 4D visualization combines the intuitive task sequencing from PERT/Gantt charts with the spatial awareness conveyed by 3D CAD models to bring forth problems and inconsistencies in engineering construction schedules.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Capital construction projects are large-scale engineering enterprises in terms of costs and durations. Typical investments range from hundreds of thousands to millions of dollars. Design and construction can last several years, while operation and maintenance span decades. Examples include modern buildings, city infrastructure and Oil & Gas process plants. Their size and complexity demand tight coordination between diverse engineering experts (e.g. structural, mechanical, electrical) and stakeholders (e.g. owners, contractors, suppliers).

To overcome these challenges, the Architecture, Engineering and Construction (AEC) industry is actively researching methods and tools based on Building Information Modeling (BIM) [27]. BIM systems go beyond traditional CAD drawings, creating a centralized database of 3D objects with diverse engineering attributes and relationships [5]. This integrated technology supports collaborative work processes that increase the quality of designs and plans. Construction and later facility management benefit from faster information access and reduced uncertainties, decreasing costs and shortening deadlines [94].

Throughout the years, different visualization techniques have been applied to improve analysis and decision making over 3D BIM models [23]. These virtual designs can be enhanced with 4D visualizations (3D + time) for virtual construction planning. Engineers can easily identify, analyze and communicate problems regarding spatio-temporal aspects of construction processes. More accurate and reliable plans consequently reduce waste and improve productivity.

Despite all these potential benefits, BIM-based 4D visualization systems are yet to be widely adopted in real-world AEC projects [51,76]. This can be traced back to limitations in the analytical features provided by existing solutions [49]. They typically follow the same principal logic: an animation of 3D objects appearing over time according to their construction sequence [71]. This limits the visual analysis to individual snapshots of the entire construction plan. Additionally, task durations and inter-dependencies are not evident and must be inferred from the animation sequence. Typical scheduling problems such as spatio-temporal simultaneity are also not immediately apparent.

We aim to improve the effectiveness of BIM-based 4D visualizations for virtual construction planning. Our first contribution is an overview of previous research, through which we highlight difficulties inherent to 3D CAD representations, best practices and typical limitations of existing solutions. Our second contribution is a list of the main design requirements for 4D construction schedule analysis, based on the literature and the consultation of experienced AEC professionals.

Motivated by the shortcomings in previous research, we present our third contribution: the design of an innovative 4D visualization system named CasCADe. Its core concept is to map time information as a spatial dimension to create an effect of cascading equipment in a 3D exploded view (Fig. 1). This unique environment brings several advantages over existing approaches. A general overview of the entire construction plan is now always available: at any moment, it is possible to glance upwards or downwards to identify future or past activities. Moreover, relative positioning between 3D geometries intuitively indicate tasks that occur simultaneously and physically near each other. We also describe several analytical tools developed to highlight spatio-temporal issues in the underlying construction schedule.

CasCADe was collaboratively designed and evaluated by AEC professionals using the real-world construction schedule of an Oil & Gas process plant. We describe how it helped the experts identify and understand several issues in this large-scale engineering project. The results of this study motivated the oil company to improve its work processes for future enterprises. We believe the proposed framework opens-up new opportunities for visualization research in the AEC industry.

div.head: RELATED WORK
div.p: This section identifies the challenges inherent to 3D CAD representations and presents an overview of traditional 4D visualizations. Table 1 summarizes the main difficulties in visualizing information within 3D CAD models. Issues 1 and 2 are related to distinguishing 3D geometries in a complex scene. Outlines are typically used to identify individual components and spatial relationships [20,53]. Other options include tone mapping [24,64,82] and luminance enhancement [70,95]. Richer illumination models also improve perception, e.g. ambient occlusion [88,99] and real-time shadows [7,40,114].

div.head: Challenges in 3D CAD Representations
div.p: Issues 3 and 4 are common in large and complex 3D CAD models. Small-scale details help users recognize areas and locate components of interest. However, too many visual features can overload the user's perception. To find the right balance, visualizations can aggregate uninteresting details [18,29], replace them with simpler abstract representations [38,87] and provide users with lenses to indicate which areas they are most interested in [100,104].

Issue 5 is inherent to any 3D representation: depending on the point of view, nearby objects can occlude others behind them. Many techniques have been proposed to overcome this, depending on particular characteristics of different problem domains [30]. Finally, Issue 6 reflects the difficulty in navigating across large virtual scenes. One solution is to constrain camera movement to pre-defined paths or surfaces [43,60,96]. Another approach is to present visual aids so users can better understand their virtual point of view [34].

div.head: 3D CAD Issue
div.p: Related Work

div.head: Distinguish individual components
div.p: Geometry outlines [20,53] Tone mapping [24,64,82] Luminance enhancement [70,95] 2. Increase depth perception Ambient occlusion [88,99] Real-time shadows [7,40,114] 3. Handle varying geometry scales Visual clustering [18,29] 4. Reduce visual clutter Simplified representations [38,87] Magic lenses [100,104] 5. Overcome occlusion Volumetric probes, virtual x-ray, multiple views [30] 6.

div.head: Facilitate virtual navigation
div.p: Limited movement [43,60,96] Visual aids [34]

div.head: Traditional 4D Visualizations
div.p: One of the earliest research on 4D CAD visualization for the AEC industry, in 1994 [21], combined the 3D CAD model with schedule information to visualize the evolutionary stages of construction. The result was a discrete animation where 3D objects appear over time, following their fabrication and assembly sequence. Additionally, colors were used to distinguish critical and non-critical activities. At any given moment, the 3D view presented the construction status of all building components, while the user could control the current date and animation speed. This visualization has become the standard method of presenting temporal information combined with 3D CAD models. Later, research focused on facilitating the generation of construction schedules [1,33] and linking them with 3D models [3,73,74]. The following subsections describe the proposed visualization schemes of additional selected publications.

div.head: Work Space, Site Utilization and Safety
div.p: 4D CAD visualizations support planning construction site layout and occupancy. Physical areas can be automatically identified from schedule data [2] to manage spatial conflicts on the job site [41,69] and to highlight safety risks during construction works [119]. Semi-transparent volumes and color maps are the most common visualizations techniques to classify these regions of space in 3D CAD models.

div.head: Coordinated Multiple Views
div.p: To facilitate analysis of diverse construction information, coordinated multiple views are associated with the 4D CAD model to display context-sensitive data for resource allocation [19,56] and cost management [98]. Examples include hierarchies, line-of-balance diagrams, data tables and time series plots, as well as frameworks to arrange multiple views according to the needs of different users [11,12,35,66].

div.head: Abstract Graphical Overlays
div.p: Lean construction methods focus on visual management to improve collaboration between multi-disciplinary teams [4]. Following these principles, 4D CAD visualizations were enhanced with symbolic representations as abstract graphic overlays to convey work flow, resource demand and construction status [85] or to call attention to high-risk activities [45]. Similar works explored user annotations to highlight construction issues within the 3D CAD model [75].

div.head: 3D Scanning and Augmented Reality
div.p: The evolution of image sensing technologies has enabled automated data acquisition directly from the job site. Laser scanners can track deviations and defects during construction [118], and even determine activity progress [105]. A related line of research employs augmented reality techniques to merge real-world photographs with the 4D CAD model in a single view [39]. Later, laser scanners were combined with color imaging to distinguish the materials of real-world objects [42]. More recently, researchers explored the use of photographs and videos to supplement and even replace laser data [115].

div.head: Exploded Views
div.p: Previous researches have demonstrated the usefulness of exploded views to convey spatio-temporal relationships between components of interest. Applications range from visually exploring volumetric datasets [14], examining equipment assemblies [68] and navigating through architectural models [79]. Other works have also explored this concept for assembly planning of complex mechanical parts [22,25].

div.head: Space-Time Cube
div.p: Time-geographical studies have proposed a 4D visualization technique named the space-time cube. It allows for spatio-temporal analysis of events on maps [65,77] and other applications in general [6]. A typical use case is to trace 4D event trajectories as lines [36] or stacked colormapped bands [101]. Another goal is to identify clustering patterns through heat maps and 3D plots [67], or proportional symbols and volumetric rendering [78].

div.head: Limitations of Previous Approaches
div.p: In the preceding review, the majority of 4D CAD visualizations followed the same paradigm. Temporal information was represented as a discrete animation of CAD objects appearing to illustrate construction progress. This environment was often supplemented by additional information visualizations: (i) semi-transparent volumes indicated site occupancy and safety-critical areas; (ii) coordinated multiple views presented schedule-related data using tables and graphs; (iii) graphical overlays like texts and symbols provided contextual information. Previous researches have investigated some of the limitations in these approaches. A cognitive experiment with AEC professionals concluded that discrete animations interfere with the user's perception of task durations, sequencing and inter-dependencies. [17]. Another research investigated how changes to the 3D objects' colors and contour lines could instead convey durations and relationships [9]. More recently, interviews with construction experts identified many shortcomings in traditional 4D visualizations [16]. The authors proposed several design guidelines for future applications, such as: adapted views for each actor, overview and details-on-demand, colors to dictate activity type and progression, and transparency to distinguish importance. The following list summarizes the main limitations in 4D CAD visualizations:
• Schedule overview is not practical since at any given time parts of the 3D model that correspond to future tasks remain hidden;
• Activity duration is not apparent and must be derived by the length of time that corresponding 3D objects remain "in-progress";
• Predecessor and successor relationships are not directly presented and must be inferred by the sequence of appearing geometries;
• Spatio-temporal simultaneity is not evident, making it difficult to avoid work-space conflicts in the construction site;

Unlike these traditional animations, CasCADe explores the concept of mapping time as a spatial dimension. Previous researches have studied this approach in exploded views and the space-time cube. CasCADe differs from these by focusing on the detailed analysis of individual events at fixed locations over extended periods of time. Instead of looking for overall trends and patterns, its analytical functions are designed to make evident fine-grained characteristics and relationships, such as event durations, inter-dependencies and spatio-temporal overlaps.

div.head: DESIGNING CASCADE
div.p: This section describes CasCADe's development methodology and identifies the main requirements for 4D construction schedule analysis.

div.head: User-Centered Methodology
div.p: CasCADe's development followed a user-centered design methodology: domain experts were involved from the beginning in requirements analysis, throughout implementation and testing [86]. This research is part of an ongoing partnership with a major oil company, whose professionals work closely with academic researchers using real-world datasets. Three collaborators were involved: (1) Schedule specialist with 15 years of experience (industrial engineer); (2) Field inspector with 9 years of experience (civil engineer); (3) Piping and equipment specialist with 11 years of experience (mechanical engineer). They participated in regular review sessions in an iterative design and implementation process. These meetings were fundamental to better understand user tasks and collect design suggestions through informal interviews. This feedback guided the concurrent development of CasCADe's visualization framework and analytical functions.

div.head: Task and Data Requirements
div.p: Engineering construction schedules contain diverse types of planning information. Some are numerical quantities, such as work durations, which can be displayed using color mapping. Others define categories, like assemblies that belong to the critical path. These can be made evident by highlighting their corresponding physical entity. In addition, schedule data can be related to different kinds of physical support, i.e. individual geometries or spatial regions. These requirements were classified by task and data type to help select appropriate visualization techniques [59]. The following list summarizes the main use cases involved in 4D construction schedule analysis (for a more detailed specification, see the The first two use cases consist in acquiring a general understanding of the construction plan and determining which activities need to be further inspected. The AEC professionals typically spend more time in use cases 3-5, where they carefully examine prioritized assemblies and validate their constructability. This order matches the visual-information seeking mantra of overview first, zoom and filter, then details on demand [90]. Sect. 5 further explains these user tasks and relates them to the analytical features implemented in CasCADe. This non-exhaustive list presents only the fundamental requirements found in past literature, as supplemented by the three interviewed AEC professionals.

Existing BIM solutions only partially satisfy use cases 1, 4, 5 and 7. No single application provides a wide array of analytical functions over the construction schedule. Unlike these approaches, CasCADe was designed to completely satisfy use cases 1-5, which determine whether a construction schedule will be feasible in practice. CasCADe's goal is to provide a single feature-rich information visualization in two ways: (i) by supporting a wider variety of user tasks in the same 4D environment; and (ii) by providing more than one visual technique to simultaneously display temporal information (e.g. graphical overlays and color-coding). This strategy facilitates the correlation of different metadata and promotes a broader and deeper understanding of the underlying construction plan.

div.head: PROPOSED VISUALIZATION FRAMEWORK
div.p: This section describes the main concepts behind CasCADe's visualization framework.

div.head: Background Concepts
div.p: Traditional approaches to construction planning focus only on the temporal aspect of schedule activities through Gantt charts and PERT network diagrams. These 2D views do not capture the spatial aspects necessary to create a truly executable construction plan. Recent research proposed many enhancements to these environments: overlays for classifications, links and highlights for relationships and comparison between multiple schedules [103]. For future work, the authors suggested extending their approach to 3D CAD models.

Parallel to this, studies on BIM have demonstrated many benefits in integrating and presenting non-spatial information within 3D CAD models [63,80,93]. These systems improve communication and collaboration between specialist teams [13,71], likely because the 3D environment explores the domain expert's cognitive memory to identify components of interest and relate them with surroundings [37,46,61].

div.head: Cascading Visualization
div.p: CasCADe introduces a 4D visualization framework that uniquely combines the main features of 2D and 3D environments. Its main principle is to use one of the 3D CAD model's spatial coordinates to present time, similar to PERT/Gantt charts. Geometries are translated vertically along the z-axis according to the finish dates of corresponding schedule tasks (Fig. 2a). This way, the remaining x and y coordinates preserve crucial information about each activity's location at the job site.

All geometries, regardless of their original elevations in the 3D CAD model, are mapped along the z-axis using the same frame of reference: a horizontal plane, located at the bottom of the vertical time axis, which represents the "current reference date". This avoids any ambiguity when visually relating nearby geometries in the 4D environment. The final z coordinate of each object is computed using the following equations:

These equations perform a linear mapping of the task's finish date (FinishDate task ) against the currently available time range (LastDate plot − CurrDate). If the fractional term is greater than 1.0, the task lies above the vertical time axis (Fig. 2b). The user can change the current date (CurrDate) and adjust the plot area to handle any time scale: days, weeks, months or years (Days Interval ); how much far ahead in time to examine (Count Interval ); and the vertical size in scene units (Size plot ). In addition, the entire plot can be translated vertically (Z plane ), away from the remaining scene's visual clutter. Table 2 enumerates the analytical functions implemented within Cas-CADe's visualization framework. Different use cases and tasks from Sect. 3.2 guided the design of each set of tools, as well as recommendations from previous research [16]. The following subsections describe which problem-solving tasks are facilitated by these functionalities and compares them with related techniques from the literature.

div.head: ANALYTICAL FEATURES OF THE CASCADE SYSTEM
Overview Schedule
div.p: The AEC professionals typically begin schedule review sessions by cross-checking recently completed activities and verifying the remaining construction sequence. The 3D perspective camera in the proposed visualization framework can introduce difficulties in visually correlating geometries in time and space [91]. To prevent this, the system provides projection aids to identify task finish dates ( Fig. 5a) and locations on the job site (Fig. 5b).

Previous work suggested animations can be used to attract attention, engage the user and provide a narrative context that facilitate learning [48,84]. Following these precepts, CasCADe implements an animation to enhance perception of time evolution and task sequencing (Fig. 3). As simulation progresses, the system translates downwards schedule-related objects, one step closer to the horizontal reference plane. Geometries that cross this boundary are automatically positioned at their target locations in the 3D CAD model. Fig. 3: Sequential snapshots of CasCADe's 4D animation.

div.head: Prioritize Tasks
div.p: Given the size and scope of a construction schedule, the engineering experts need to prioritize detailed activity analysis to maximize efficiency. This typically involves looking for discrepancies and anomalies in the temporal metadata associated to each 3D CAD component. CasCADe color-codes geometries to call the user's attention to these inconsistencies ( Fig. 4a). Studies on human perception have determined that colors are useful in labeling categories and mapping quantitative data [102,110]. Researches have also shown that different color mapping schemes are more suitable to different applications [10,47,92]. In CasCADe, the user is free to choose any schedule metadata to be presented using one of its many configurable palettes [17,44]. The engineering collaborators requested the ability to create a customized metric associated with the color mapping. Their motivation was that simply looking at individual attributes is often not sufficient to identify certain kinds of inconsistencies. Therefore, CasCADe allows for a custom mathematical formula to be input in a text box using predefined symbols and constants. This unique functionality opens up the possibility of different kinds of analysis, e.g., estimating probability of delays, leveling resources between simultaneous activities, comparing planned vs actual work execution, measuring costs vs productivity.

After selecting activities of interest, the user can activate fo-cus+context shortcuts for more detailed inspection [117]. As shown in Fig. 4b, focused geometries are highlighted with colored contours while context is provided by surrounding semi-transparent geometries. When color-coding is active, double-clicking on one of the legend's colors automatically moves the camera towards corresponding 3D components and sets the remainder of the scene as transparent. The user can also quickly toggle visibility of non-selected activities as a means to reduce visual clutter [28]. Note this is not possible in traditional 4D CAD animations, where visibility already conveys time information.

div.head: Examine Metadata
div.p: During detailed analysis, the AEC professionals inspect quantitative data associated with each construction task. They look for inconsistencies on start and finish dates, durations and other attributes. Usually, problems are identified by cross-checking different fields over different activities. Therefore, the visualization must be able to simultaneously present diverse characteristics of the underlying schedule.

A typical approach in BIM has been to implement coordinated multiple views (Sect. 2.2.2). The visualization literature has studied this technique extensively with great success [57,58,81,83,109]. It supports exploratory analysis through the simultaneous display of different aspects of the same underlying dataset. CasCADe takes a fundamentally opposite approach to achieve the same goal. As described in Sect. 4, the proposed framework combines multiple types of visualizations into a single 4D view. This simplifies the users' visual analysis tasks by focusing their attention on a single display where data correlations are immediately evident. This approach is similar to multi-layered visualizations in geographical information systems (GIS) [26,112].

Many of CasCADe's analytical functions can be activated simultaneously to present different metadata over the 3D CAD model [32]. The cascading view and visual projection aids make evident finish dates and task sequencing. Additional linked views display the product hierarchy and schedule metadata in tabular form. These attributes can also be shown directly over each 3D geometry using texts, numbers and symbols. On top of that, different temporal information can determine the geometries' color-coding. Finally, semi-transparent volumes indicate activity durations, similar to 3D bar charts.

div.head: Inspect Relationships
div.p: Construction schedules inherently contain many kinds of relationships between activities, e.g., explicitly defined predecessors and successors that indicate hard dependencies between construction works. Another example is the critical path: activities that cannot be delayed without impacting the final project deadline. A third type of correlation between activities is seldom explored: the physical and functional interconnections between facility components. This information is crucial to determine the most effective assembly sequencing to anticipate testing of subsystems. Although these three examples are fundamental in a construction schedule, the majority of existing 4D CAD solutions fail to appropriately support their analysis (Sect. 2.3).

CasCADe fills this gap by graphically representing relationships between construction works. It preserves geometries from past and future activities always visible so the entire scene can be visually related. The system draws colored highlights and links between 3D components according to different types of relationships: predecessors/successors, critical path or plant operating system (Fig. 5c). This design explores the user's familiarity with traditional 2D time visualizations, e.g. Gantt charts and PERT networks. Other researches have also explored this representation to display both 2D and 3D graphs [8,50,89,111].

div.head: Plan Site Layout
div.p: A reliable and executable plan also needs to consider the handling of facility components at the job site. Physical areas need to be prepared and isolated in order to adequately and safely conduct programmed activities. For example, falsework may need to be installed to provide access to hard-to-each places, while heavy machinery may be required to move large components. In addition, pre-fabricated materials are often gathered in the area to reduce logistics delays. Consequently, the AEC collaborators emphasized the need to identify occupied work spaces and any spatio-temporal conflicts between simultaneous activities.

CasCADe uses semi-transparent volumes to indicate work areas, like previous BIM research (Sect. 2.2.1). However, the proposed visualization framework enables an enhanced visual representation of these areas over time. Each 3D work-space volume is stretched along the vertical time dimension (z-axis), according to the activity's start and finish dates. The resulting "4D envelope" conveys two important pieces of information: the space occupied by each activity and its duration in time. This functionality also enables the automatic identification of scheduling conflicts through 3D collision detection. Robotics research has long explored a similar approach to plan the motion of machines [15,97]. Many real-time algorithms have been proposed to detect collisions in interactive graphics applications [52,55,62]. CasCADe implements a bounding-volume hierarchy to quickly identify overlapping work-space volumes and highlight them in red for the user (see Fig. 5d).

div.head: IMPLEMENTATION
div.p: CasCADe is a multi-platform Windows/Linux application developed in C++ using GCC/MinGW. The user interface is implemented with the Qt framework and rendering uses OpenGL. The graphics engine initially implemented the order-independent transparency (OIT) algorithm from [72]. However, the users found it hard to distinguish between overlapping geometries. The depth complexity of 3D CAD models still presents a great challenge in maintaining visual quality with OIT techniques [31,113,116]. Moreover, the oil company discarded a solution based on ray tracing due to the costs in hardware necessary to render large-scale and dynamic 3D CAD scenes in real time [107,108].

div.head: USER EVALUATION
div.p: The three collaborators evaluated CasCADe using the real-world construction plans of an existing Oil & Gas process plant. Subcontractors were responsible for defining the schedule, while the owner company supervised task planning and execution. The schedule contained 646 construction tasks, among which 127 corresponded to equipment assembly in the field. Throughout the design and implementation of CasCADe, the company conducted schedule review sessions to identify problems and inconsistencies in this construction plan [54].

div.head: Schedule Uncertainties
div.p: The first step was to review the overall construction schedule and its critical path. The overview provided by our unique 4D visualization was essential to analyze past, present, and future activities. The collaborators emphasized the ease of perceiving relative ordering between tasks and their actual locations in the construction site.

Plotting time vertically immediately made apparent several uncertainties in the underlying schedule. The professionals repeatedly found cases where a large number of construction works with long durations were programmed to be executed in parallel. Fig. 6a exemplifies how the developed visualizations were applied in these scenarios. These parallel tasks would compete for shared construction resources (e.g. materials, heavy machinery, and assembly crew). In addition, diverse equipment would arrive simultaneously at the job site, increasing storage and logistics costs. Typically, when compared to similar activities, the durations of these parallel works proved to be unusually high.

The 4D visualization also exposed another problem: the aforementioned tasks did not involve the critical path of the construction schedule (Fig. 6b). It would be a great challenge to accurately level resources and meet the simultaneous demands of both the critical path and those other assemblies. Such examples justify demanding the subcontractors to further detail the construction plan. In these cases, a more sequential scheduling, considering the available work crews, could minimize temporal overlap and promote just-in-time delivery of goods. In the end, these changes would increase assembly productivity and avoid unnecessary storage costs.

div.head: Work-Space Conflicts
div.p: During the review sessions, CasCADe helped the engineering collaborators to find several work-space conflicts in the equipment assembly plan. Fig. 7a presents one of the situations identified automatically by the software. In this particular case, one of the assemblies would start one month after the other and both would finish at the same time. The experts used the developed visual tools to further analyze the underlying schedule and confirm these kinds of inconsistencies.

In this case, the projection aids proved to be useful in checking the final assembly location of each equipment. As indicated in Fig. 7b, one of the geometries would be built on the floor above the other. The engineers noted that the assembly task on the superior floor would demand the isolation of the entire area for safety concerns. If this workspace conflict was not observed prior to task execution, it could lead to high-risks for construction workers on the floor below. By improving this assembly sequence, it should be possible to avoid idle teams and unused materials that would be left in the job site.

div.head: Custom Risk Metric
div.p: During real-world construction works, the subcontractors regularly adjust the schedule according to physical advance and unforeseen difficulties. The owner company must oversee these changes to avoid any new inconsistencies in the construction plan. The collaborators used CasCADe's custom-metric feature to conduct a visually guided risk analysis. Their goal was to determine which assemblies had the higher probability vs impact of compromising the schedule. Special attention was dedicated to analyzing the constructability of these activities. The following equation presents the metric devised by the experts:
div.formula: Priority = (Num pred + 1) * Duration base * (Num suc + 1) Float f ree * √ Float total + 1(3)
div.p: In Equation 3, the dividend combines the delay probability of a particular task with its impact on the overall enterprise. The probability is given by two measures: number of predecessors (Num pred ) and baseline duration (Duration base ). The higher the number of predecessors, the higher the chance of an assembly being delayed by a previous one. Similarly, large durations correspond to complex and/or uncertain activities that are more likely to face unforeseen problems. The impact is quantified by the number of successors of a given task (Num suc ): how many pending works would be negatively affected by any delays. The divisor mitigates the overall metric by the task's free float (Float f ree ) and total float (Float total ). The free float represents the amount of time that a task can be delayed without affecting any of its successors, whereas the total float indicates the maximum delay that would not affect the project's final deadline. Because of its impact on the overall schedule, the total float is given higher importance by a square root operation. Smaller float values correspond to lower error margins, thus increasing the overall risk metric.

Applying Equation 3 in the developed 4D visualization highlighted one heat exchanger in particular, as shown in red in Fig. 8a. Compared to similar equipment throughout the plant, there is no justification for its excessively long assembly duration. This brought additional evidence of the lack of detail in the schedule devised by the subcontractors. Different assembly tasks corresponding to equipment of the same kind were planned to last anywhere from 9 up to 110 days. This level of variability and uncertainty would make it nearly impossible to accurately manage resources and logistics in the job site.

The metric also identified the construction of the plant's stack as a "high-risk" activity. It was properly scheduled to start assembly before its connecting furnaces, which were related as predecessors/successors in the construction plan. However, the 4D visualization indicated an overlap between the stack and furnace assemblies (see Fig. 8b). In this situation, the furnaces would arrive at the construction site while the area was still restricted by the stack's construction works, resulting in delays and increased storage costs. Using the operating system highlight of our 4D visualization, it was possible to verify which other equipment could be impacted by this problem.

div.head: USER FEEDBACK
div.p: Throughout this research, the collaborating engineers provided valuable design guidelines and feedback. Afterwards, we conducted an interview with a series of open-ended questions on three themes: (1) What were the main benefits and limitations of the proposed 4D visualization? (2) Which analysis tools worked best and which needed improvement? (3) What other kinds of schedule revision tasks should be supported?

Overall, the experts demonstrated a high degree of satisfaction with CasCADe, often highlighting the intuitive perception of task sequencing and their locations on the job site. They also praised the ease to analyze diverse time information in the same view using different visual effects. One standout functionality was the focus+context navigation shortcuts, which quickly highlighted and moved the camera towards geometries of interest. All participants deemed fundamental the ability to customize the visualization by toggling effects and editing the color-coding metric.

Some participants had difficulty in navigating through the 3D environment and requested additional camera shortcuts; for instance, for switching the point of view between plotted geometries and their final assembly locations. Another improvement would be to consolidate the many visualization options into predefined templates geared towards different kinds of analysis. For future work, the domain experts suggested the visualization of additional construction information such as workforce and materials, and the ability to compare two schedules in order to investigate alternative plans and follow work execution.

The oil company is currently implementing several changes in its work processes thanks to feedback from CasCADe's evaluation and is already planning to apply the system in its next engineering enterprise.

div.head: CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
div.p: BIM research has shown the potential benefits of 4D CAD visualizations for virtual construction planning of large-scale engineering projects. Our work has aimed to improve the effectiveness of these techniques following best practices from information visualization. First, we conducted a review of previous visualizations in the literature. We then interviewed experienced AEC professionals to consolidate a list of design requirements for 4D construction schedule analysis.

These two contributions guided the design of CasCADe, a novel 4D system that overcomes many shortcomings of traditional methods. The proposed visualization framework maps time as a spatial dimension to create an effect of cascading geometries in a 3D exploded view. This creates an intuitive environment similar to PERT/Gantt charts where Fig. 8: The collaborators used CasCADe's customized metric to colorcode high-priority activities: (a) heat exchanger in red with unusually long duration; (b) work-space conflict between the process plant's stack (red) and its two adjacent furnaces (green). general overview, task sequencing, and spatio-temporal simultaneity are immediately evident. We also described how the developed analytical tools are assembled into an information-rich visualization for virtual construction planning.

The engineering collaborators used CasCADe to review the realworld construction plans of an Oil & Gas process plant. The system brought forth uncertainties from the lack of predecessor/successor relationships and tasks with excessively long durations. Overall, Cas-CADe identified both large-scale issues related to task detailing and sequencing and small-scale ones pertaining to work-space conflicts and constructability. The results motivated the oil company to improve its work processes and to apply the solution on its next enterprise.

CasCADe provides a strong base for future research in information visualization for the AEC industry. As mentioned in Sect. 6, new orderindependent transparency algorithms could robustly handle the high depth complexity of 3D CAD models. These techniques could even automatically highlight features of interest, similar to rendering of volumetric datasets [106]. We also wish to explore techniques for reducing visual clutter and call attention to data inconsistencies, like magic lenses and simplified geometry representations (Sect. 2.1). Finally, Sect. 3.2 suggests additional use cases that could be explored by future works. In particular, developing analytical features to compare construction schedules should bring interesting visualization challenges.

figure.head: Fig. 2 :
figure.figDesc: The proposed cascading visualization enables an overview of the entire schedule (a) and highlights future construction works (b).

figure.head: Fig. 4 :
figure.figDesc: Techniques for identifying and focusing on activities of interest: (a) color-coding highlights schedule discrepancies; (b) focus+context shortcuts use transparency to bring forth occluded geometries.

figure.head: Fig. 5 :
figure.figDesc: Examples of visual tools for detailed task analysis: (a) horizontal lines towards the time axis distinguish nearby finish dates; (b) overlay texts present contextual information while vertical lines indicate assembly locations; (c) coordinated views convey additional schedule information while green/blue highlights and links identify predecessor/successor relationships; (d) semi-transparent volumes indicate task durations, occupied areas and work-space conflicts (in red).

figure.head: Fig. 6 :
figure.figDesc: CasCADe made evident schedule uncertainties: (a) many parallel assemblies with unusually high durations; (b) these assemblies (blue bars) would compete for resources with the critical path (in red).

figure.head: Fig. 7 :
figure.figDesc: Example of work-space conflict found by the engineering collaborators: (a) simultaneous scheduling of two vessels is made evident by overlapping geometries and volumes (in red); (b) safety risks would prevent execution of these activities on floors above one another.

figure.head: Table 1 :
figure.figDesc: Visualization issues inherent to 3D CAD representations.

table included in the supplementary material): 1. Overview Schedule: correlate activities with CAD components, identify past and future works, analyze construction sequencing. 2. Prioritize Tasks: identify activities with min/max metadata or unusually low/high values.3. Examine Metadata: verify numerical quantities such as start, finish, duration, free and total float.4.Inspect Relationships: identify critical path, predecessors, successors and facility subsystems.5. Plan Site Layout: locate activities in the job site while determining occupied work areas, safety risks and logistics.6. Alternative Scenarios: compare differences in activity types, relationships and metadata between alternative construction plans.
figure.note: 7. Follow Work Execution: identify ongoing activities, follow their physical progress and compare planned vs execution.

figure.head: Table 2 :
figure.figDesc: Visual analysis functions implemented in CasCADe, their motivating use cases and related research from the visualization community. Items in italic indicate repeated occurrences of the same function.

row.cell: Color coding, custom metric, focus+context shortcuts
Graphical overlays, linked views, cascading view, projection aids, color coding, semi-transparent volumes
Coordinated multiple views [57, 58, 81, 83, 109] Geographical information systems [26, 112] Quantitative data analysis [32]
Semi-transparent volumes, cascading view, projection aids

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
div.p: The present work was done with support from CNPq, Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico -Brasil (processes 140933/2014-0, 311620/2014-0, 309828/2015-5 and 453996/2014-0). The authors wish to thank the reviewers for their valuable comments and suggestions. The authors also thank André Souza and Francisco Queiroz for their help with document formatting and editing of the supplementary video.
